#Text=Bolek
#Text=This article is about the Seminole chief .
#Text=For the French World War II intelligence officer with this code name , see Gustave Bertrand .
#Text=For the Polish cartoon character , see Bolek and Lolek .
#Text=For the secret agent Bolek , see Lech Wałęsa §Wałęsa and secret police .
#Text=Bolek ( died 1819 ) , also spelled as Boleck or Bolechs , and known as Bowlegs by European Americans , was a Seminole principal chief , of the Alachua chiefly line .
#Text=He was the younger brother of King Payne , who succeeded their father Cowkeeper ( known to the Seminole as Ahaya ) as leading or principal chief in Florida . [ 1 ]
#Text=Bolek succeeded King Payne in 1812 when he was killed .
#Text=Early life and education
#Text=Bolek was one of several children born to Ahaya ( Cowkeeper ) and his wife .
#Text=He and his older brother King Payne were groomed by their mother 's brother ( in the matrilineal kinship system ) to become chiefs and take leading roles among the Seminole .
#Text=They inherited that role through their mother 's people , who were descended from the Alachua chiefly line .
#Text=Bolek was designated as a village or itwála chief while a young man ; he was based near the Suwannee River of western Florida .
#Text=He began to oppose United States influence in Spanish Florida during the early 19th century .
#Text=He prevented Georgia slaveholders from entering Seminole territory to pursue escaped slaves from the Low Country .
#Text=Some of the fugitives married into the Seminole people ; most created independent communities nearby as allies and were known as Black Seminoles .
#Text=They kept much of their Gullah culture and developed the Afro-Seminole Creole language in Florida , which they used through the 19th century .
#Text=In 1812 , Bolek and his brother King Payne began raiding frontier settlements along the Florida-Georgia border .

#Text=Seminole bands fought several engagements with militia forces ; Payne was killed in 1812 , and Bolek suffered serious wounds during the same skirmish against Georgia militia forces under Daniel Newnan . [ 2 ]
#Text=An expedition by Colonel John Williams the following year destroyed hundreds of Seminole villages and captured numerous horses and cattle .
#Text=Border warfare between the Seminole and Georgia settlers contributed to US involvement in the Creek War of 1813-1814 .
#Text=Seminole Wars

#Text=During the First Seminole War , beginning in 1818 , American forces under General Andrew Jackson advanced into northern Florida capturing Kinache 's village of Miccosukee and occupying the British settlement of St. Marks before reaching Bolek 's abandoned village .
#Text=They captured two Englishman , Robert Ambrister and Peter Cook , who were taken back to St. Mark .
#Text=Charged with assisting the Seminole , they were executed by American forces .
#Text=Although this created an international incident , Jackson continued his offensive and recaptured Pensacola .
#Text=The US purchased Florida from Spain in 1819 , and the Seminole expected they would have more to do to try to keep the Americans from their territory .
#Text=Bolek died that year and was succeeded as principal chief by his maternal grandnephew , Micanopy .
#Text=Micanopy was principal chief through the move into central Florida and the Second Seminole War .
#Text=He also led the Seminole to Indian Territory , realizing that trying to fight the US superior forces was finally futile .
#Text=In the West , he worked to gain separate territory and independence for the Seminole from Creek oversight until his death in 1849 .
#Text=He was succeeded by his sister 's son , John Jumper , who died in 1853 .

#Text=John 's younger brother , Jim Jumper , succeeded as principal chief , leading the Seminole in Indian Territory until after the American Civil War , when the United States government began to interfere with tribal succession .
#Text=Another member of the Cowkeeper dynasty was Billy Bowlegs .
